number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 16, 2013
												Squirrel's seal of approval: GoldWhy I played: One of my irl friends got a four pack so me, him, and 2 other irl friends could play monaco together on release. I will admit that I was surprised by how good this game was.Should you play:  If it is on a sale, it is a great buy. If you like stealth and co-op games this is for you. Even if you don't play much indie games like me, you should have some fun. Recommended controller input: Keyboard/Mouse, Xbox stylye controllerPros+Great art style+Great soundtrack+Extremely well balanced classes+Good stealth mechanics+Good UI+Easy to pick up and play+Good controls+Funny dialogue+Good level design+Great co-op+Extremely easy to provide developer inputCons+Repetitive+Not much fun without friendsRunabilityCan run on a toaster, trust me, burrito played it xDVerdictWhile this game is very fun, it does not last long. I do suspect my in-game time for this won't get much higher anytime soon, but I have to say this game is great.One of the great things about indie games is how it is usually way easier to voice your opinions to developers. In fact, with monaco, I know of some developers' steam accounts, so I can ask them questions or give feedback. It makes me feel like I am helping them achieve something, and it makes me feel good.9/10

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 6, 2013
												Monaco has very simple mechanics: walk into things to use them, line of sight the gaurds/civs, and steal everything of value. The classes pretty much do the same thing as the next class can do but are specialized in some actions. Locksmith picks locks and safes fast, Pickpocket hides in bushes fast, etc etc. Some classes have special abilities as well, like Mole can dig into most walls, Redhead can charm enemies, etc etc.Unlike most stealth games, Monaco doesn't end when you're seen. Your score isn't based on how stealthy you are, but how fast you cleared the level with coins missed adding time. It's a ton of fun when you're with 4 people, alarms are going off, and everybody is disorganized.Despite the simple mechanics, it's a challenging game. Towards the end you're up against SWAT guys with shotguns who can pretty much 2-3 shot you from accross the room so STAY HIDDEN!UPDATE DEC 21 '13: I should note that the game comes out with free updates. Last update came new game mechanics like pickpocketing keys off gaurds to unlock doors in the mission or "buttcash" (people used to stand on top of coins, now they have wallets) which should have been in the game from the start but is in now. Last update also nerfed some of the difficulty in a lot of the missions in order to allow for all players to get through the game.

content:
Posted: January 2, 2014
												Monaco is one of my favorite games, and probably will remain so. From my perspective, its meant to be played co-op and not too seriously. Because it doesn't take itself too seriously. You and three of your friends (or three strangers on the internet) get to run, hide, steal, and generally cavort your way through tons of zany levels. And due to the amazing level editor, the content does not stop when you finish the story mode. Its tons of fun, so go buy it! You won't be disappointed. This game knows that even without the most advanced graphics, perks, or features, its all about gameplay, and Monaco's gameplay cannot be beat.

												To call Monaco a stealth game would be like calling a dandelion food. While technically it is, if you are eating a flower you are probably doing it wrong. In the same way, Monaco is more of a cooperitive game then a stealth game. That isn't to say that it's a bad stealth game, in fact it's one of the best that I've ever played. It just that it's so much better with friends. The best parts of the game are when one player saves the rest of the party and completely turn the hiest around. Even playing online is better than playing solo. So if you are looking to spend a weekend with friends, this is the game to play.

												Immediately upon launching the game from Steam gives an error message stating to "restart Monaco via Steam to play online, etc."  It doesn't tell you that you must turn on Steam Cloud. Users are forced to use Steam Cloud just so one single game can work the way its supposed to, which is completely broken from a programming standpoint.  If you're too lazy to code a working game / API that works as advertised then you get a thumbs down.  I haven't even played the game yet.  I've wasted 45 minutes trying to sort this out.  I don't tolerate ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t like this.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 21, 2014
												Monaco: What's Yours Is Mine is a 2D game where form a group of four along each character's stories. Playing alone is not recommended, additionaly, there are only a few lobbies to join in(or at least in my region) compared to when it had a ''free day''. It became boring to me after a day because of the lack of lobbies.Each session has its thrills and a whole lot of vibrant colours, even in screenshots. If you don't find it cheerful, your vision is my concern. As for the audio, I can't really say much; I was too busy collecting coins for my shotgun. As for the missions, I am glad they are assorted. They're not all prison breaks or heists, but I haven't finished the game so I can't really say more than that. I have played it long enough(I think) to say it though.The game doesn't have an atmosphere as it does not need any(though it would be more impressive if there was) because it is a fast-paced multiplayer, however, every random lobby has a random story; all three of you are in the stairs to the next leve-- wait, three? THREE? Well, you just found out one of your teammates got shot and now you have to get to him before advancing. One of you decides to do it, only to die in the process too(noob lol), you go ahead and get rushed by three guards, and the last one? Cowering in the ladder. After a minute of trying to convince the last guy, he eventually gets out of his spot and saves all three of you.But now your score is extremely low, which sucks. True story(Told it in Second-Person View so it wouldn't be that confusing with words).And so it comes to the generalization:Gameplay: 19/25Graphics: 15/25Concept: 17/25Presentation: 15/2566/100-----------------------------------------I think you'll like it for the first five days(in raw hours), so yes, I recommend Monaco: What's Yours Is Mine to you, the reader of this review. And please do give feedback so I could make my reviews more readable and helpful--JustOak

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 1, 2014
												When I first got Monaco , I found it boring. I'm not an experienced gamer , and didn't know much about Monaco itself . I struggled a bit and didn't know how to go online .However , after about half a year of not playing it , I decided to give it another go . I loved it . I was hit with an exciting stealth game , which was cunningly designed . I adore the look of the game and its great how each character has its own little personality. But I have to say online mode is the best . Its not about stealth - its about set all the alarms of and run . I must've spent hours online playing with people all around the world , howling with laughter one minute , then reviving a player the next minute. The whole design of the game mixed with the beautiful music makes it a really good game to play alone , or multiplayer . Apart from the occasional crash ( after returning to desktop a few times it fixes it ) ,and not being able to make my own levels ( for some reason this just didn't work ) the whole game ran smoothly for me . I definately reccomend this game to anyone !

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 21, 2014
												By far one of the greatest local and online co-op games I know.This game can be played either solo or multiplayer, via lan or online. Although beware of local co-op. You will share the same screen, and depending on the strength of your computer and pupils of your eyes, the map expands and becomes smaller on the screen. This may be irritating for some, therefore I highly suggest playing co-op via online or lan.The game utilizes lots of timing and patience, yet feels very puzzle-like with a rush of adrenaline. The most charming appeal I found was how the layout of the levels you play are like blueprints of the venue you are robbing. You get to play through a series of characters with their individual special techniques. I suggest mastering all characters, and if you're new, start with Gentlemen and learn how to sneak. There are multiple possibliities of completing missions and you'll most likely never complete a mission like previous trials. When you play multiplayer, the game becomes more entertaining as new challenges with the actions of other players. You can either work in concert as a team, or watching the hilarity of chaos ensue as your teammates flee to save themselves from trouble. Regardless of your teams ability to play well, if you've mastered this game and understand its timing, you won't be frustrated with your teamates or the layout of the map, and you will want to find more competitive players/theives.Once you've gotten used to the game mechanics and obstacles, solo and co-op speed running becomes the new, neverending challenge. Beating these maps at the fastest speed becomes the ultimate reward.This game isn't for everyone, but it's certainly a new and innovative way of playing co-op.10/10

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 28, 2014
												Monaco is probably one of the best co-op experiences to be found on Steam. It is very easy to pick up, yet difficult to master all of it's fine nuances. The difficulty curve is well balanced (though some complain that it becomes too hard near the end, I personally disagree) and has plenty of content.When Monaco was launched, it only came with the main campaign. Now there are an additional two campaigns, (one retelling the events of the game in a new perspective, and one telling the backstory of each of the main characters) a Zombie mode for all missions and a higly robust level creator. There is a final campaign coming as well.The pixelated, minimalist graphics style is bursting with tiny visual effects and charm. Your mind tends to fill in the gaps where the graphics don't give detail, further adding to the charm of hiding in bushes to evade guards.The sound is also fantastic. The music contributes to the atmosphere and the sound effects are meanigful as well.The co-op play is best experienced with friends in the same room. After a brief time of figuring out the game, players will be trying different strategies and utilizing each of hteir abilities to clear the levels. Having each player be a different character helps to have each player feel like they are making a meaningful contribution to the team. However, with more players, the chances of one player being spotted increaces, which makes for some of the best moments. One player being chased leads to another, and another. If you're looking for a great co-op experience, Monaco is highly recommendable.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 12, 2013
												Monaco is a whismical, colorfully violent game.  It boasts an intriguing story, one-of-a-kind art direction and soundtrack, and the kind of cooperative gameplay and mechanics we haven't seen since Gauntlet: Dark Legacy.  It improves on that formula in almost every aspect, bringing true cooperation to the modern era outside of Left 4 Dead and Left 4 Dead 2.  Every character has their own distincy personality, color and playstyle, and it's super fun to figure out which one would be best for each encounter.  A single round can turn from meticulous planning to outright chaos in seconds, and no matter how you play, it's just a blast.    And what's even cooler, is that the community is the most civil I've ever seen.  Perhaps it's the lack of a competitive element, or how it's impossible to do well solo, but people just love this game, and are super cool about who plays as who.  TL;DR:  BUY THIS ♥♥♥♥ING GAME.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 25, 2013
												Let me give it to you straight, Monaco is a fantastic and lovingly crafted game.  At its most basic, it's pac-man meets Hitman.  That said, it's not for everyone.  It throws out the old way of viewing stealth in favor of a more tense, skin of your teeth heist feel.  Getting caught is no longer time to restart the checkpoint, but merely a situation that you must, and can, deal with.  Getting caught is fun, and the emergent situations you find yourself in are a joy to work your way through.  Perfectionists may get a little angry, as "perfecting" a level may require use of getting caught to make quick navigation easier.Where the game shines though, is the glorious Co-Op.  You approach the structure previously chosen to raid.  You plan meticulously.  Everything is going smoothly, but one person screws one thing up.  Insanity and a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ amount of fun ensues.If anyone picks this up I'm always game for some Co-Op.  In fact that's the main reason I bothered to write this.------------------------------------------------------TLDR-----------------------------------------------------Stealth game with a dose of uncontrolled insanitySuper fun Co-Op
